data.title: Revisit getWorkspace-API
data.body: We have added the `getWorkspace`-api with some special behaviour in case it's called with the path of a workspace. Not every expected that it behaves like and we should (1) have a flag to make it behave different, e.g. return the workspace folder if called with one and (2) consider changing/breaking the defaults

data.title: Implement local file system provider
data.body: Just because we can, because it will help with running the extension host somewhere, and to align the code we should strive for a [`IFileSystemProvider`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/platform/files/common/files.ts#L178) that works against the local disk (basically what we have today in another implementation of the fileService). Also, it will show if the provider story is strong enough, what pieces are still missing. @bpasero How much confidence do you have the [fileService tests](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/services/files/test/node/fileService.test.ts)?

data.title: Highlighting of variables in the scrollbar area
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-ins
- OS Version: win7x64

Highlighting of the variables in scroll area works by weird selective algorithm and totally unefficient.

I see that it's trying to be "smart" highlighting, but in fact - it's not.

Just to understand what I mean, you better see the GIF:

![hightlighting - scrollarea](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/30747096-d3c3b214-9fb4-11e7-9e1d-7283e7441e46.gif)

You mark up "onDragCancel" in one area of the code - no highlighting in scroll area.
You mark up the same "onDragCancel" in another area - and one more appear in the bottom of the code.

Then you mark up "dragObject" that has been put as an argument (20+ times written in the code) - and NO highlighting at all.

Should be fixed.

data.title: Non-standard selection overwrite behavior
data.body:
In most text editors and IDEs, typing after making a selection *overwrites* the selected text.

In VS Code, sometimes, when you try to type over a selection, the editor instead inserts next to or around the selected text.

For example, while editing a Typescript file here:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/103348/30744430-54aff648-9fa2-11e7-97eb-38ac252ec8c3.png)

If I try to replace the selection with a double quote, this happens:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/103348/30744452-686a18da-9fa2-11e7-91d2-a41f627b33a9.png)

data.title: Distribute in a non-zip package for Mac (.dmg, .pkg) to avoid dock issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

As reported in #13389, attempting to pin VSCode to the Mac dock can result in the shortcut failing to work after restarting VSCode or rebooting, with the icon being overlaid with a '?'. As I describe at https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/9293#issuecomment-331422359, this is due to Apple's AppTranslocation (aka Gatekeeper Path Randomization) sandboxing that according to https://lapcatsoftware.com/articles/app-translocation.html occurs for zip-distributed apps under certain circumstances. See #13389 for more details including repro steps.

data.title: Test: New RelativePattern support in extension APIs
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/34157

- [x] Windows - @mjbvz 
- [x] Linux - @jrieken
- [x] macOS - @kieferrm 

Complexity: 3

We have 3 places where we ask for a file glob pattern:
* `workspace.createFileSystemWatcher`
* `workspace.findFiles(include, exclude))`
* `DocumentFilter#pattern`

To make it easier to scope a pattern to a `WorkspaceFolder`, we introduced `RelativePattern` which allows to specify a base and a pattern to match against. Only file paths that are within that base file path are considered a match for the pattern. 

**Verify:**
* the documentation around the 3 APIs mentioned above makes sense and is helpful
* you can use the 3 APIs from your extension and they work with either `string` or `RelativePattern` as documented.

**FYI - to test against the latest API do the following:**

open your extensions package.json file
change the engine.vscode property to *
run npm run postinstall (assuming you have the vscode module as dev-dependency)
undo the engine-version change from step 2

data.title: [Feature Request] - Disable and Enabling Extensions
data.body:
Visual Studio Code x64
Version: 1.16.1

**What is happening:**
I notice that when we "Disable (Always)" an extension, when I want to enable it again I can't just enable for that workspace, I need to enable Always again. 

**What I want**
I can  "Disable (Always)"  for the default behavior, but Should let I "Enable (Workspace)". 

**Why?**
It's good to have some plugins that is disabled by default and I enable only when I need without the needing of enable it always.

**Thank you**

data.title: Can't find npm module!
data.body:
VSCode Insider can't find node modules even they exists in the project root.
Happens after upgrade.

- VSCode Version: Version 1.17.0-insider (1.17.0-insider)
- OS Version: Mac Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Import module in a ts file: 
`import { Component } from '@angular/core';`
2. Error: 
`[ts] Cannot find module '@angular/core'.`

I noticed that it affects all the angular modules e.g. `@angular/http`, `@angular/material`, `@angular/router` and `@angular/forms`

data.title: Smarter workspaceContains handling?
data.body:
Would it be possible to avoid a full workspace scan from every `workspaceContains` that an extension declares by stopping a search once the first result is found? I know that this should work from the classic file traversal implementation but I am not sure about `RipGrep`. Maybe there is a command to use `RipGrep` in such a way that it would just return 0 or 1 when a result is found?

Alternatively we could also do a heuristic: we could first do a quick check of the root level files of the workspace folders and only run the more expensive file search if no files match. I would argue that in most cases the file of interest would actually be in the root folder (e.g. `tsconfig.json`).

data.title: Can we have a Open in the right pop up menu on the files view
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

I have icons, sound files, batch files and other files that I would like to "open/run" or "edit" natively with the right click menu on the file view so I can quickly run the file or edit the file with it's native editor.

For example I can Open a Batch File in explorer or I can Edit. I can play a sound or edit it with audacity... Explorer's right click menu gives me both options. Same with a Sound File and so many others. the system allows this so might as well use it!

Related, the Reveal in Explorer should be in it's Own group which would also have the "open" Native and, if the "edit" options is present, the "edit" Native

Sorry for the bold large font
Menu Change Suggestion:
Open to the side
Open in Terminal
-
Open In Explorer
Open/Run Natively
Edit Natively (This menu may or may not be available, hidden/grayed if "edit" command is not registered for the file type)
-
Copy
Copy Path
-
Rename
Delete

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
2.

data.title: When I try to open multiple editors with Ctrl+P each one replaces the previous one
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any source file with Ctrl+P
2. Open another file with Ctrol+P. 

Effect: The second file opens in the same tab. Instead of having the 2 files open only the last one remains.
